author: .vbuterin
content: Or put another way, an EIP 1559 spike long enough to raise the gasprice by 10x is equivalent to a natural spike that already happens due to random block time variance roughly once a week

author: holiman
content: We've started seeing 0-gasprice txs in blocks, at 'sweet spot' positions -- obviously MEV geth where miner is paid for tx inclusion on the side. Would the mechanisms for such behavior change any, with 1559? There would be a mandatory burn, right?

author: sky.cactus
content: Yes, with 1559 there is a mandatory burn which must be paid by the transaction signer.

author: sky.cactus
content: This is bad for the people doing the extraction, because it means they need to fill their accounts with ETH.  This in turn is arguably bad for the network, because these people tend to move a lot of ETH to a lot of accounts.

author: sky.cactus
content: We *could* make it so the miner can choose to pay for the transactions out of the coinbase account, accounted for at the end of the transaction (so after miner has been paid other fees and block reward).  This would likely have the net effect of reducing the total number of accounts created and ETH moved around because those MEV bots would likely often use fresh accounts for their stuff, rather than using/needing seeded accounts.

author: sky.cactus
content: Downside of course is increasing 1559 complexity a bit.  Hard for me to say if it is worth it or not to enable miners to cover base_fee or not.

author: .vbuterin
content:

> We could make it so the miner can choose to pay for the transactions out of the coinbase account,

author: .vbuterin
content: The problem is that that would require a block to also have a signature from the coinbase

author: .vbuterin
content: Not a problem in eth2, but for now...

author: sky.cactus
content: I think we could avoid that need by saying the base fees covered could not exceed the block reward + transaction fees.

author: sky.cactus
content: More complexity though.

author: .vbuterin
content: right, and there's definitely been cases before where fees have exceeded rewards
